direction.raw_text: .C. - AFTERNOON An afternoon in late November, the leaves have left the trees, and the early darkness of a winter dusk approaches. The garden is long and narrow, guarded on either side by a high brick wall. At one end stands the rear of a three-story brick townhouse; at the other, a one story brick building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is heard in the distance. A MAN, handsomely dressed in a well-tailored suit of the 1920's, works in the garden. A gardener's apron protects his suit from the earth as he turns the loam along one of the walkways. He works slowly,-precisely, obviously engrossed in his surroundings. This man is called CHANCE. Chance stops working for a moment, takes a pocket watch from inside his coat, checks the time. He looks to the darkening skies, returns the watch to his pocket. As Chance starts toward the one story brick building, he takes a spotless rag from his apron pocket and wipes the dirt from the tines of his pitchfork.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The sound of the music increases as Chance enters the garage from the garden. A gleaming 1921 TOURING CAR is revealed as he walks through the garage and leans the pitchfork against a wall. Chance takes a neatly folded cover from a shelf, carefully puts it over the car. When he finishes covering the car for the night, Chance picks up the pitchfork, leaves the garage through a side entry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Potting Room is filled with the tools of the gardener, everything arranged in an orderly fashion. Rows of small pots are on tables, young plants sprouting from some of them. A small, 1940's table model black-and-white TV rests on a shelf. It is playing, tuned to the BOSTON POPS ORCHESTRA. Attached to the front of the screen is a wheel containing colored gels. The wheels spins, creates an early form of color TV. As Chance enters, his attention is on the television set. He watches it as he oils the tines of the pitchfork and puts it away. Chance turns off the TV and leaves the room, but the sound of the Boston Pops continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A room adjacent to the Potting Room. A large screen remote control color television set dominates the room. It is on, tuned to the Boston Pops. In contrast to the new TV, the rest of the room is sparsely but tastefully decorated with expensive furniture of the twenties. There are no books, magazines, newspapers or reading matter of any kind to be seen. Chance comes in, watches the TV with a detached gaze as he removes his apron. He changes the channel with the remote control as he puts his apron and the pitchfork rag into a laundry bag. He takes off his suit jacket, hangs it in the closet where it is accompanied by several others, all of like quality. Chance changes the channel once again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance, wearing a different suit and carrying the laundry bag, crosses from the rear building to the main house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The interior of the main house has the mustiness of age, the warmth of oak. White dropcloths and sheets cover all of the furniture. Chance enters, walks through the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large dropcloth is over the dining room table and chairs. It is neatly folded back at one end, leaving one chair and place setting uncovered. A small portable color TV is next to the place setting. Chance enters, puts his laundry bag on a covered table near the doorway. He sits at the dining room table, turns on the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and carefully unfolds his napkin, puts it on his lap as he watches the screen. LOUISE, an elderly black maid, enters with a tray of food and Chance's clean laundry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Evening, Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Good evening, Louise. Louise sets Chance's clean clothes on the small table, picks up his laundry bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... The Old Man is getting weaker, Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid he's slippin' a bit with every hour that goes by... Chance, his manners impeccable, concentrates on the TV as he eats. A buzzer SOUNDS, Louise looks upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Back up those stairs - damn... That Man's needin' me more and more just before he never needs me again...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is his back feeling better? Louise gives Chance a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Gobbledegook... You and your gobbledegook. You're gonna be the death of me yet, Chance... (she turns to leave) ... Unless those stairs are... The Good Lord's liable to snatch up two unwillin' souls at the same time if I keep on trampin' up those stairs... I don't want none of that... Louise disappears through the doorway. Chance continues to eat and watch TV.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (slowly, perfect diction, no accent of any kind)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Chance is asleep, lying on his back. His eyes slowly open, and, with no change of expression, he sits up and turns on the TV with the remote control. Chance gets out of bed, goes to the dresser and takes his pocket watch out of a drawer, checks the time. He crosses to the closet, his eyes never straying from an early morning show on television. He puts on a bathrobe and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance enters, turns on the TV with the spinning color wheel, then waters a few of the pots with a sprinkling can. He turns off the TV and exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance comes into the garage, takes the cover off of the touring car, folds it and puts it on a shelf. He leaves the garage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance returns to his room, changes channels on the television, takes off his robe and hangs it back up in the closet, then goes into the bathroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A light snow is falling. The door to the small building opens, Chance peeks out, then goes back inside. A few seconds pass and Chance reappears, this time with an umbrella. Smartly dressed in suit and tie, he crosses to the main house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance opens the door, shakes off and closes the umbrella before entering. He hangs the umbrella on a doorknob, then heads for the dining room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Repeating his ritual, Chance enters the dining room, sits, turns on the TV, carefully spreads his napkin on his lap. He watches the screen for a moment, then turns, expecting Louise. She doesn't appear, so he turns back, watches TV. After a few beats, Chance hears Louise's footsteps hurrying down the stairs. She comes into the dining room, visibly distraught. Chance looks up, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Louise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's dead, Chance! The Old Man's dead!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must of happened durin' the night, I don't know... Lord, he wasn't breathin' and as cold as a fish. I touched him, just to see, and you believe me, Chance - that's doin' more than I get paid to do... Then I just covered him up, pulled the sheet over his head...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I've seen that done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I got the hell out of that room and called the doctor and I think I woke him probably, he wasn't any too alert. He just said, 'Yeah, he's been expectin' it and said he'd send somebody over...' Lord, what a mornin'!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes, Louise, it's snowing in the garden today. Have you looked outside and seen the snow? It's very white. A beat of silence from Louise, then anger.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dammit, Boy! Is that all you got to say? More gobbledegook? (Chance smiles, is silent) That Old Man's layin' up there dead as hell and it just don't make any difference to you!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Louise. I have seen it often. It happens to old people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, ain't that the truth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It is. Louise throws back the cover from a chair next to Chance and sits, softening a bit toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Lord, Chance - I don't know what I was expectin' from you... I'm sorry for yellin' like I did... No sir, I just don't know what I was expectin' ... (Chance doesn't react, watches TV) ... I 'spose I'd better gather up some breakfast for you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I'm very hungry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, no more stewin' those prunes every mornin', that's somethin', I guess... (she starts out, stops by the door) ... what are you goin' to do now, Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm going to work in the garden. Louise gives Chance a long look, then turns to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'll get you some eggs. Chance nods in approval, then changes the channel on the TV.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (watches news, flashes of season's first snowfall)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An enclosed stairway. Chance enters, proceeds up the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance comes out of a doorway adjoining the main staircase. He moves off down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The furniture in this room is not covered with sheets but the Old Man is. There is a polite knock at the door, then Chance enters the room. As Chance moves slowly to the Old Man's bed, we sense a feeling of respect from Chance, as well as a bit of curiosity. Chance stands by the side of the bed for a moment, then he reaches down and gently pulls the sheet back from the Old Man's face. He touches the man's forehead, lightly, briefly, then replaces the sheet. Chance moves to the TV (like the one in his own room) and turns it on. He sits in an easy chair next to the Old man's bed and watches a movie from the early forties. Chance puts an arm out, rests it on the Old Man's covered body. With the other, he changes the channels with the remote control. He returns to the channel with the forties movie and seems to become absorbed in a scene in which a gentleman tips his hat to a lady. The scene seems to have 'sunk into' his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It has stopped snowing. Chance, wearing a hat, the gardening apron over his suit and boots, putters in the garden. Louise comes out of the main house. She is dressed warmly, a scarf over her head, a heavy coat. Chance sees her, tips his hat to Louise exactly like the man he saw on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Well, ain't you the gentleman this mornin'... (a pause) ... gotta go now, Chance...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna need somebody, someone's gotta be around for you, boy... (he keeps working) ... You oughta find yourself a lady, Chance... (she smiles slightly, with caring) But I guess it oughta be an old lady, 'cause you ain't gonna do a young one any good, not with that little thing of yours... (she reaches out, puts a hand on his shoulder) ... You're always gonna be a little boy, ain't you? (he smiles, keeps working) ... Goodbye, Chance... Louise gives his shoulder a squeeze, turns and moves toward the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Goodbye, Louise. Louise waves as she enters the townhouse. Chance tips his hat once again as she disappears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Louise enters the hallway, picks up a couple of suit cases waiting by the door. She stops as she sees TWO MEN in white carrying a stretcher down the main staircase. She notices the ease with which they bring the Old Man's body down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... He used to be a big man... 'Spose he wasted away to about nothin'... (a beat - then she talks to the body of the old Man) ... I guess I'll be goin' off to find me some folks, Old Man... I'm not batty enough to stay around this neighborhood any longer... The stretcher bearers move to the front door. Louise steps in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait up! I'm goin' out that door first. Louise takes one more look at the covered body, then opens the front door, leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TV plays offstage as Chance washes up in the bathroom. He finishes, comes into the bedroom, takes a pair of house slippers from his closet, turns off the television and leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance, carrying his slippers, crosses through the layer of fresh snow to the townhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance, wearing the slippers, enters and sits at his place. He turns on the TV, puts the napkin on his lap. He watches TV for a moment, then turns, looks for Louise. She does not appear so he resumes watching TV. He changes channels, views a wildly exciting FOOTBALL game. At a peak in the excitement, he again switches channels. Chance watches TV News coverage of the PRESIDENT of the United States greeting foreign dignitaries at the White House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S on television reveal that the President uses a two-handed handshake when meeting his guests. Unconsciously, Chance grips one hand with the other, the scene on TV seeming to have 'sunk into' his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A key is heard in the lock. The door opens and THOMAS FRANKLIN and SALLY HAYES enter. Franklin, an attorney, is in his late thirties, carries a large briefcase. Hayes is younger, attractive, also an attorney. She totes a briefcase, has the look of a modern, liberated woman. Hayes appears to be surprised at the interior of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... This is another world, Tom - I never would have believed it...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... He and my father used to ride together back in the thirties... Fox hunting... Before I was born...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Would you take me on a tour?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gladly... (he smiles) ... The safe is in Mr. Jennings' bedroom, that'll be stop number one. Franklin puts a hand on Hayes' shoulder as they,go off down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance still watches TV, waits for Louise to serve him. Franklin and Hayes appear in the doorway of the dining room. They are both surprised to see Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Why... Hello, we thought we heard something... (moves to Chance, hand outstretched) I'm Thomas Franklin. Chance remains seated, takes Franklin's hand warmly in both of his like the President did on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Thomas... I'm Chance, the gardener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... The gardener? (thinks it's a joke, laughs) ... Yes, of course... Mr. Chance, this is Ms. Hayes. Hayes moves to shake Chance's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chance, I'm very pleased to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Chance turns back to the TV and Hayes and Franklin exchange looks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... We're with Franklin, Jennings and Roberts, the law firm handling the estate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Thomas - I understand. Another period of silence. Franklin and Hayes seem perplexed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Are you waiting for someone? An appointment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I'm waiting for my lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your lunch? You have a luncheon appointment here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Louise will bring me lunch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Louise?... The maid?... (a look to Hayes) But she should have left earlier today...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You've quite a sense of humor, Mr. Chance - but all kidding aside, may I ask just what you are doing here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I live here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You live here? (a look to Hayes) ... We don't have any record of that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It's very cold outside today, isn't it, Thomas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... How long have you been living here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ever since I can remember, since I was a child.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since you were a child?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Thomas. I have always been here. I have always worked in the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Then you really are a gardener?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your appearance doesn't suggest that at all, Mr. Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you have any proof of your employment, Mr. Chance - any checks from the deceased, any contracts or documents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How were you compensated for these duties you say you performed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Compensated...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How were you paid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was given meals, and a home...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about money?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never needed money. Franklin steps to the TV, turns it off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chance, perhaps you could show us some identification with your address -- a Driver's License, a credit card, checkbook?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I do not have any of those.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then how about medical records? Could you give us the name of your doctor, or your dentist?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no need for a doctor or dentist. I have never been ill. I have never been allowed outside of this house, and, except for Joe, I have never had any visitors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Joe? Who's Joe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Joe Saracini. He was a mason that did some repairs on the brickwork at the rear of the house. That was in 1952.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I remember when he came. He was very fat and had short hair and showed me some pictures from a funny little book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some pictures...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Of men and women.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chance, that was twenty-seven years ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes and the Old Man used to come to my garden. He would read and rest there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, Mr. Jennings had been bedridden for thirty-five years, since he fractured his spine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Thomas, that is correct. Then he stopped visiting my garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... We shall need some proof of your having resided here, Mr. Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have me, I am here. What more proof do you need? Franklin and Hayes exchange looks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (doesn't rise, again shakes with both hands)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Chance puts on his snow-boots as Franklin and Hayes continue their questioning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you served in the Army?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Thomas. But I have seen the Army on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How about taxes, Mr. Chance, surely you must have paid taxes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Chance picks up his slippers and leads the attorneys outside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance describes his garden with pride as they walk toward the rear building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those trees were very young when I first arrived.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you related to the deceased, Mr. Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I don't think so. And I have planted and shaped all the hedges, and in the springtime you will be able to see my flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Might you have a birth certificate, Mr. Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. (points to wall) That's where Joe fixed the bricks. They arrive at the rear building and Chance opens the door to the garage. Franklin and Hayes follow him inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin and Hayes are taken aback by the touring car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Do you drive this, Mr. Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Thomas. I have never been in an automobile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You never been in a car? Chance is silent for a moment, he blushes slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Well... From time to time I did sit in it... Just in here... It hasn't been outside since the Old Man hurt himself. (he turns) I live in here. Chance moves toward his room, Franklin and Hayes follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance sits on the bed to remove his boots as Hayes and Franklin inspect the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Old Man gave me nice television sets, this one has remote control. (he turns it on with the remote) He has one just like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chance, the fact remains that we have no information of your having any connection with the deceased.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I understand. Chance puts on his slippers, crosses to the closet, opens the door. It is filled with men's wear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am allowed to go to the attic and select any of the Old Man's suits. They all fit me very well. I can also take his shirts, shoes and coats.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is quite amazing how those clothes have come back into style.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I have seen styles on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What are your plans now, Mr. Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like to stay and work in my garden. Chance turns to watch TV. Franklin takes Hayes to a side of the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... What do you make of all this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I really don't know, Tom - he seems so honest and simple... In a way, he's quite charming...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yeah...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It's very bizarre - I don't know what to think...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... He's either very, very bright or very, very dense - he's hard to figure... (he unzips briefcase) ... Let's just keep everything legal. Franklin takes out some papers, approaches Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Chance, assuming what you say is the truth, I would like to know what sort of claim you are planning to make against the deceased's estate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm fine, Thomas. The garden is a healthy one. There is no need for a claim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. That's good. Then if you would please sign a paper to that effect. Franklin hands the release to Chance but Chance does not take it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Thomas. I don't know how to sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, Mr. Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no claim, Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you won't sign, correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Correct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very well, Mr. Chance - if you insist on dragging this matter on... But I must inform you this house will be closed tomorrow at noon. If indeed, you do reside here, you will have to move out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Move out? I don't understand, Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you do, Mr. Chance. However, I will reiterate, this house is closed and you must leave... (he gives Chance his business card) Call me if you change your mind about signing. (turns to Hayes) C'mon, Sally - let's grab a bite...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day, Mr. Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day, Sally. Chance watches as they leave, then puts Franklin's card on a desk without ever looking at it and turns to stare at television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A large attic filled with the Old Man's possessions of the past. Chance enters, turns on an old black-and-white TV with a magnifying lens attached to the front. As it plays, he selects a fine leather suitcase from several, takes a hand made suit from a long rack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TV is on as Chance packs his belongings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance, very nicely dressed, comes out of the rear building carrying his suitcase. He stops on occasion to inspect his garden as he walks toward the townhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance is reluctant to open the front door. After some hesitation, he gathers up his courage, opens it and steps outside, closing the door behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance stops short on the front steps; the townhouse is situated in a decaying ghetto. The snow is a dirty grey, houses adjoining have their windows shattered, are smeared with grafitti. Chance tries to return to the safety of the townhouse, but the door is locked. He stands on the steps for a moment, then moves to the trash laden sidewalk. He stops, ponders which way to go, finally makes up his mind and moves off to his left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The buildings are crumbling, rusted out cars line the street. A group of Black people huddle together in threadbare stuffed furniture on the sidewalk, a fire burning between them for warmth. Chance rounds the corner, walks up to them. He stands by them, smiles. They stare back, no sign of friendship in their faces. Chance nods politely to them, then walks away down the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. - AFTERNOON A group of eight to ten hard-core ghetto youths hang out on a corner. Other passersby give them a wide berth, they are unapproachable. Chance nears the group, approaches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Excuse me, would you please tell me where I could find a garden to work in? They turn to him as one, silent, amazed that this White trespasser would intrude on their jiving.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... There is much to be done during the winter, I must start the seeds for the spring, I must work the soil... One of the Black youths, LOLO, interrupts Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you growin', man? The leader of the gang, ABBAZ, shuts up Lolo with an elbow and moves menacingly forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... What you doin' here, boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had to leave my garden. I want to find another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bullshit. Who sent you here, boy? Did that chickenshit asshole Raphael send you here, boy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Thomas Franklin told me that I had to leave the Old Man's house, he's dead now, you know...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead, my ass! Now get this, honkie - you go tell Raphael that I ain't takin' no jive from no Western Union messenger! You tell that asshole, if he got somethin' to tell me to get his ass here himself! (edges closer to Chance) You got that, boy? Chance smiles at Abbaz and reaches into his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I understand. (he takes out his remote control TV changer) If I see Raphael I will tell him. Chance points the changer at Abbaz and clicks it three times, tries to change the picture. Abbaz immediately pulls out a switchblade, whips the blade open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, move, honkie! Before I cut your white ass! Chance, disappointed that the changer did not work, returns it to his pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Of course. (as he leaves) Good day. Abbaz, Lolo and the gang watch him go, then begin to buzz with excitement: "Who the fuck died?" "Why'd he pull that changer on us, man?" "The Old Man died, must be Papa Joe!" "He's some weird honkie, man."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. - AFTERNOON A Bulletin board affixed to a storefront in Chinatown. Chance gazes at the notes pinned to it, written in Chinese. Smiling, he turns from it, walks on through the area.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. - AFTERNOON A street lined with adult book stores, X-rated movies and strip joints. An elderly Black woman approaches carrying a bag of groceries. Chance steps in front of the woman, stops her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very hungry now. Would you please bring me my lunch? The woman looks up to Chance, becomes very frightened. She turns and half-runs into a sleazy bar for safety. Chance watches after her for a moment, then continues along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. - AFTERNOON Chance stands looking through a chain-link fence watching some teenage boys playing basketball. He bangs on the fence, calls to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have seen your game! I have watched Elvin Hayes play it many times! They call him "Big E!" The boys ignore him, Chance walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. STREET - LATE AFTERNOON Chance walks down the center meridian of a divided street. He seems oblivious to the automobiles passing on either side. In the background can be seen the Washington Monument.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. STREET - LATE AFTERNOON Chance seems stumped on which way to go. He looks up one street, then the other, has no idea where they lead. He turns, looks behind him and sees a large statue of Benito Juarez pointing. Chance smiles and goes off in the direction that Benito points.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tourists are gathered around gaping through the fence at the White House. Chance is turned the other way, inspecting the branches of a dying tree. Chance moves to a POLICEMAN standing nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me... (points to tree) ... That tree is very sick. It should be cared for. The Policeman looks at the tree, then at Chance, figures a man dressed that well must be important.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. I'll report it right away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That would be a good thing to do. Good day.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day. The Policeman takes out his walkie-talkie as Chance walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A fashionable area. Expensive shops, well-kept streets and sidewalks. A television store has caught Chance's eye. He stands by the display window, looks in at a dozen or so color TVs, all turned on, playing various channels. A video camera points outward from a corner of the window and is focused on the sidewalk to allow potential customers to see themselves live on an Advent TV. Chance is intrigued by his own image. He poses, lifts one arm, then the other to make sure that it is really him on television. He moves forward, smiles, then moves slowly backward, notices himself become smaller on the screen. He steps back off the curb, frowns as his likeness disappears from frame on the Advent. Standing between two parked cars, Chance takes out his remote control, clicks it at the Advent. Four or five other sets in the window change channels, but he does not reappear on the giant screen. As he does this, the car to his,left, a large, American-made limousine, backs up. The car bumps Chance, pins him against the car to his right. Chance cries out in pain, drops his suitcase, his changer, and bangs his hand on the trunk of the limo. The chauffeur, DAVID, and the liveryman, JEFFREY, immediately jump from the car, run back to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very sorry, sir... I... David and Jeffrey reach out to help, but Chance is wedged solidly between the two cars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I can't move... My leg...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... My Lord...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is terrible, sir -  I hope you're not badly injured...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm not badly injured. But my leg is very sore. David pulls the car forward, freeing Chance. A few bystanders begin to gather as Jeffrey helps Chance to the sidewalk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you walk? It's not broken, is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's very sore. David gets out of the car, comes back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps I should call an ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: interrupts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody ought to call the police!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no need for police, it's just my leg. During this, the rear door of the limo opens and EVE RAND steps out. Eve is in her late thirties, has the look of a traditional New England lady. She watches as Jeffrey tends to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think we should call anyone just yet, it may not even be all that serious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's have a look, do you mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. I would like to look. Chance bends, raises his trouser leg. A red-bluish swollen bruise, three inches in diameter, is forming on his calf.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's starting to swell, is it painful?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Eve moves closer to Chance, looks at the bruise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Won't you let us do something for you? Your leg should be examined, we could take you to a hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no need for a hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, there certainly is. You must see a doctor, I insist on it. Please, let us take you. Eve turns to get back into the limo. David goes with her to hold the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm terribly sorry, Mrs. Rand, I never saw the man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I don't think it was anyone's fault, David. DAVID Thank you, ma'am. Chance is hesitant about getting in the car. Jeffrey offers a helping hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've never ridden in an automobile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I assure you, sir, David is a very careful driver. Please, won't you let us take you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes. You can take me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good. Jeffrey assists Chance into the rear seat of the limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... My suitcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. I'll take care of that. Jeffrey closes the door, goes back to pick up Chance's suitcase, does not notice the remote control. As Jeffrey puts Chance's bag into the trunk, we see the personalized license plate "RAND l."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance and Eve settle in the back seat. As they talk, David starts up the limo, Jeffrey joins him in front and the limo pulls out into traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope you're comfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: These can be such trying situations everyone seems to make such a to-do over a simple little accident. Of course, they can be very frightening, and I must apologize for David, he's never had an accident before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. He's a very careful driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Why, yes, he is... Is your leg feeling any better?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's feeling better, but it's still very sore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. (a thought) ... Say, would you mind seeing our family doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your family doctor?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. My husband has been very ill. His doctor and nurses are staying with us. Those hospitals can be so impersonal - why, it might be hours before you are treated...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, it will save a lot of unnecessary fuss and it will be so much more pleasant for you... (leans forward) David, we'll just go on home. Jeffrey, would you call and let them know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes ma'am. Eve presses a button, the glass partition closes. As the window rolls up behind him, Jeffrey dials the limo telephone. There is a moment of silence. Eve, still a bit on edge from the accident and feeling a bit uncomfortable with a stranger in the car, presses another button. The limo's bar moves out, revealing a row of decanters and glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you care for a drink?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Thank you. As Eve pours cognac into a monogrammed crystal glass, Chance notices the limo's TV set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like to watch television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? Certainly... She hands Chance the cognac, turns on the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, by the way - I'm Eve Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Eve. Chance takes a sip of the cognac, is not accustomed to alcohol, coughs. There is another moment of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I ask your name?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon me, was that Mr. Chance?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm a gardener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... Mr. Gardiner... Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... You're not related to Basil and Perdita Gardiner are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Eve. I'm not related to Basil and Perdita.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Well, they're just a wonderful couple, we've been friends for years. We visit their island quite often. Chance reaches out to change the channel on the TV, suddenly realizes he doesn't have his remote control. He starts going through his pockets, searches for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you lose something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I lost my remote control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... Well, I'm very sorry... Another pause, Chance reaches out, changes channels on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'll feel so relieved after Dr. Allenby examines your leg. After that, David can run you on home, or to your office or wherever you'd prefer... (Chance still watches TV) ... Is there anything special you would like to watch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like to watch. This is fine. Chance watches the news. Eve sips on her cognac as David eases the limo out of the city of Washington.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The limo approaches, then turns into the entrance-way of the Rand Estate. Two guards stand on either side of the open gate, salute as the car passes through.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The drive runs alongside a stream, then turns and crosses a large meadow. The limousine passes, still no sign of the house. It is a very, very long driveway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance is glued to the TV, switches channels, again watches the news. Eve takes his fascination with television as a sign of intelligence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see that it must be very important for you to stay informed of all the latest events.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I admire that in a person. As for myself, I find there is so much to assimilate that it can become quite muddling at times... Chance nods, changes the channel, watches a Mighty Mouse cartoon. Eve looks at him perplexed, then takes it for a joke and smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two uniformed valets, WILSON and PERKINS, await the limousines by the front door of the Rand mansion. Wilson stands behind a wheelchair. As the limo parks, Perkins and Jeffrey assist Chance into the chair. Wilson turns to Eve as she gets out of the limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Mrs. Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall take the gentleman to the third floor guest suite, ma'am. Dr. Allenby is standing by.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Wilson. That will be fine. Perkins and Jeffrey carry Chance in the chair up the steps and into the house. Eve and Wilson follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Once inside the house, Wilson takes over wheeling Chance. A lady, GRETA, is waiting to take Eve's coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Greta. (to Wilson) I'll be with Mr. Rand if I'm needed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll see you after the doctor has a look at your leg, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I think he should examine my leg. Eve watches as Wilson wheels Chance around a corner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The doors open, Wilson pushes Chance into the elevator. As Wilson pushes a button and the doors close on them, a strange look comes over Chance's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I've never been in one of these. Wilson thinks that Chance is talking about the wheelchair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's one of Mr. Rand's. Since he's been ill... Chance looks around the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it have a television?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No - but Mr. Rand does have one with an electric motor, that way he can get around by himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Chance again checks out the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long do we stay in here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long? I don't know, see what the doctor says ... The elevator stops on the third floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hallway adjoining a large, glass-enclosed room. Eve passes through the hall, enters the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve enters into a hermetically sealed area, set up with all the latest hospital emergency gear; oxygen, EKG machine, X ray machine, transfusion equipment, sterilizers, etc.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: wearing a silk bathrobe, lies in a king-sized bed in the center of the room. A nurse, CONSTANCE, is attending to her duties in the room, looks up as Eve comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Mrs. Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening, Constance. Ben Rand perks up as he sees Eve crossing to him. He is in his sixties, maintains an inner strength and dignity despite the sapping effects of his illness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with weakness) ... Eve... Eve kisses him, holds his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Ben - I miss you so when I'm out... How are you feeling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tired... And I'm getting tired of being so tired. Other than that, I'm doing very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No headaches?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, it's been a good day - better than yours, from what I've been told.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You heard?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I may be a shut-in, but I do not lack for news. I'm sorry you had to go through all that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, it wasn't all that bad, darling. We were fortunate that Mr. Gardiner turned out to be so reasonable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reasonable? Good, I'd like to meet a reasonable man. Why don't you ask this Gardiner to join us for dinner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you feel well enough for that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hah!... Tell me the truth, Eve - if I wait until I feel better, will I ever meet the man? There is silence from Eve. Rand squeezes her hand, turns to Constance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constance! I want new blood tonight, I'm getting up for dinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Mr. Rand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't argue, tell Robert I want new blood! (turns to Eve) ... Ask him to dinner. Rand pulls Eve's hand close, kisses it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (sits on the side of the bed)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An enormous bedroom, filled with 18th Century antique furniture. DR. ROBERT ALLENBY dabs Chance's ass with a piece of cotton soaked in alcohol, prior to an injection. Chance stands with his pants to the floor, looks to the television which is not turned on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The injection will ease the pain and swelling, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. I've seen it done before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, you'll barely feel this. It won't hurt at all. Allenby administers the injection, Chance reacts from the pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were wrong, it did hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not for long... As Allenby puts a band-aid on Chance's ass, Chance spots a remote control for the TV on the bedside table. He reaches out, picks it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's good that there was no apparent damage to the bone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I think so, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: However, with injuries such as this, I have run into minor hemorrhaging, which really isn't too serious at the time, but can cause secondary problems if not looked after.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Chance turns on the TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can pull your trousers up, now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, fine. ALLENBY (as Chance pulls up pants) Just to take the proper precautions, Mr. Gardiner, I'd recommend we take you downstairs and X-ray your leg. (no reaction from Chance, Allenby takes a long look at him) ... By the way, Mr. Gardiner, I would like to ask you something straight out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Straight out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Are you planning on making any sort of claim against the Rand's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Claim...? ... Oh, claim, that's what Thomas asked me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas? Who's Thomas?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas Franklin, an attorney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An attorney?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you wish to handle this matter through your attorneys?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no need for a claim, the garden is a healthy one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I see... (warms up) ... Well, then... You're a very funny man, Mr. Gardiner. You caught me off guard, I must admit...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, keep your weight off that leg, Mr. Gardiner. In fact, it would be best if you could stay here for a day or two, if that would be would be possible. Since Benjamin became ill we have our own hospital downstairs. I can promise you the finest in care, unless, of course, you would prefer to go elsewhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I could stay here. Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Would you like me to speak to your personal physician?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Allenby waits for Chance to say more, he does not. Finally, Allenby picks up his bag, heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll send Wilson up to take you for X-rays, Mr. Gardiner. Feel free to use the telephone, and please let me know if you have any discomfort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I will. Allenby gives him a look, then leaves. Chance watches an old movie of a man lighting a cigar. The man enjoys the cigar, blows out smoke. The scene seems to 'sink into' Chance's mind.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (a look to the TV, then to Chance)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Eve sits next to a roaring patio fireplace with a steaming cup of tea. Allenby comes outside, joins her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good God, Eve - you'll freeze out here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wanted some fresh air, Robert. How is Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A rather large contusion, but I don't feel there is any serious damage. I'd like to keep an eye on him, though - I suggested that he stay here for a couple of days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay here? Is that necessary?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not necessary, but preferable. I don't think he'll be a bother, he seems like a most refreshing sort of man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, he is different... Not the kind of person one usually meets in Washington.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How true. Mr. Gardiner may be a welcome change of pace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's very intense, and internal, don't you think?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At times, yes. But that's not an uncommon reaction to such an accident. Actually, I found him to have quite a sense of humor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. It might be pleasant for a couple of days. (Eve puts down her tea) ... Robert... Is there any improvement...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Eve... I'm sorry. Eve is silent for a moment, looks out to the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Sometimes when I see Ben I could swear that he's getting stronger... Something that he might say, the way he moves, or a look in his eyes - makes me feel that this is all a nightmare and that he'll be better soon... It's just so hard to believe what's really happening... Allenby reaches out, holds Eve's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator door opens, Wilson guides Chance in the wheelchair into the hallway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... That is a very small room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir, I guess that's true smallest room in the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It seems to be. Wilson takes this as another joke, chuckles as he wheels Chance toward Rand's hospital room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and another nurse, TERESA, stand by as Rand is being given a transfusion. Rand lifts his head as Wilson wheels Chance into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to Rand Memorial Hospital, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I see. Wilson pushes Chance to the X-Ray machine, where the technician, BILLINGS, a Black man, waits. As Wilson and Billings help Chance onto the X-Ray table, Chance's face brightens up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel very good in here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you do. This ward is air tight, I have a little extra oxygen pumped in, keeps my spirits up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I like that very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This won't take long, Mr. Gardiner. Please hold still when I ask. Chance stares at Billings, reacts to him being Black.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know Raphael?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir, I don't believe I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I have a message for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Black man gave me the message.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I still don't believe I know the man, Mr. Gardiner. Now, hold still. Rand looks over as Billings takes the X-Ray.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aplastic anemia, Mr. Gardiner - aplastic anemia. Chance smiles to Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Failure of the bone marrow to produce red blood cells... Not a damn thing they can do about it. Oh, they can make me comfortable, prolong my life with steroid therapy and transfusions... And what makes my blood boil, what little I have left, that is, Mr. Gardiner - is that it's generally a young person's disease... Here I am, getting on in years and about to die of a young person's disease...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. You look very sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hold still, please, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am very sick, and, as you can see by all this paraphernalia, I am very wealthy. I think I would rather be wealthy and sick than poor and sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. I've never seen anything like this on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, hold still, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You too, Mr. Rand, you must stay quiet. Rand lays his head back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... We're prisoners, Mr. Gardiner - we're prisoners of tubes and technology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You will join us for dinner, won't you, Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I am very hungry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... So am I, my boy - so am I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a waiter, and MARIANNE, a waitress, enter into the Rand dining room carrying trays of food. The dining room is immense, a 70-foot ceiling, huge fireplace. Allenby, Eve, Rand, and Chance (both in wheelchairs) sit around the table. Rand speaks slowly, with obvious weakness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know exactly what you mean. Today the businessman is at the mercy of kid-lawyers from the SEC. All they want to do is regulate our natural growth! It's happening across the country!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To everyone, I'm afraid. The Government controls are so restricting that the Medical Profession, as we know it, is being legislated out of existence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course! By kid-lawyers! Eve turns to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Won't your injury prevent you from attending to business, Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. It won't do that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Would you like us to notify anyone for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. The Old Man died and Louise left. There is a moment of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. I'm very sorry. Well, if you have any need for any of our facilities, please do not hesitate to ask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you need a secretary?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you. My house has been closed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. When you say 'Your house has been closed', you mean to say that your business was shut down?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Shut down and locked by the attorneys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'd I tell you? Kid-lawyers! The S.E.C.! Damn them!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope that staying here won't be an inconvenience for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I like it here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good, Mr. Gardiner. Or may I call you Chauncey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Chauncey is fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I'm Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And please call me Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Robert. I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So tell me, Chauncey, what are your plans now? Chance looks around the room. CHANCE Does this house have a garden? Allenby gives Chance a look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do we have a garden? Hah! Tomorrow, Chauncey, you will see our gardens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. I would like to work in your garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I know exactly what you mean. I sometimes enjoy puttering around myself, such a pleasant way to forget one's troubles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a very good gardener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gardener! Well put, Chauncey excellent! Isn't that what a businessman is? A gardener? A person that makes flinty soil productive with the labor of his own hands, who waters it with the sweat from his own brow, and who creates a place of value for his family and community? Yes, Chauncey, what a brilliant metaphor
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: yes, indeed, a productive businessman is a laborer in his own vineyard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Ben. The garden that I left was such a place. Everything which grew there was with the labor of my own hands. I planted seeds and watered them and watched everything grow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I don't have that any more... (points to ceiling) ... All that's left for me now is the room upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, wait a minute, Chauncey you are young, you are healthy, for God's sake don't give up on yourself! You have to fight! You can't let those bastards keep you down! I don't want to hear any more from you about the 'Room Upstairs'. That's where I'm going soon. There is a long pause. Chance looks up, then smiles at Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a very pleasant room, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I'm sure it is. That's what they say, anyway. Another period of silence. The servants bustle around the room as Allenby studies Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allenby opens the door. Rand enters in his electric wheelchair followed by Chance being pushed by Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I don't know what you've heard about me, Chauncey, but I'm sure you know everything there is to know. Cigar? Rand holds out humidor to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, thank you. (takes cigar) No Ben. I don't know everything about you. Rand smiles as he takes a cigar for himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... No, of course you don't. Excuse me for being so presumptuous. No man knows everything about another man - however, very few are honest enough to admit it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is so true. You're different, Chauncey... Quite different than most men.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Robert. Rand lights his own cigar, then hands an ornate lighter to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You know, Chauncey, there are thousands of American businessmen, large and small, that share your plight. I've been concerned with the situation for some time now. Chance, not knowing to bite off the tip, tries to light the cigar like the man on TV. It will not light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So I've been thinking about beginning a financial assistance program, Chauncey, to help out American businessmen that have been harassed by inflation, excessive taxation, unions and other indecencies... Allenby watches Chance trying to light the cigar as Rand speaks on, shooting pool as he talks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'd like to offer the decent 'Gardeners' of the business community a helping hand. After all, they are our strongest defense against the pollutants who so threaten our basic freedoms and the well-being of our middle class. Tell me, would you have any thoughts on such a program? Chance puts the unlit cigar in the ashtray, smiles at Allenby, then answers Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctant to speak, eh, Chauncey? Well, I can understand that. When a man loses everything, anger has a tendency to block out reason for a time. Just give it some thought, work with the idea, I'm sure you'll have plenty to say in a few days.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could give it some thought, Ben, but my leg is very sore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Oh? (looks to Allenby) Robert, take a look, would you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some pain is to be expected... (bends to Chance, looks at leg) ... And I think what would be best for the two of you is a good night's rest. (checks watch) ... It's late, I'm afraid it's time for my patients to prepare for bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have common foes, Chauncey - kid lawyers and our physician!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree. Allenby laughs as he takes Rand's cigar from him, snuffs it in the ashtray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (picks up pool cue, weakly strokes the balls)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Wilson stands behind Chance in the wheelchair. Chance glances slowly and inquisitively around the elevator. When his eyes meet Wilson's, the valet breaks out in laughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Sorry, sir - I just couldn't contain myself... I knew you were going to come out with another one of your jests about the elevator... Excuse me, sir... The elevator stops, the door opens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilson wheels Chance out of the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Hmmm... Elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes sir - elevator! Wilson stops laughing, becomes the stone-faced servant once again as he notices Eve coming out of her bedroom. Wilson stops wheeling Chance, stands stiffly at attention as Eve and Chance talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, I wanted to tell you how dreadful I feel about the accident today, but that I'm delighted that you are staying with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Eve - I like this house very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And Ben is just mad about you - you've lifted his spirits so - it's just... Well, it's just a real pleasure having you with us.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben is very ill, Eve - I've seen that before.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... I know, Chauncey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like Ben very much... He reminds me of the Old Man...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Are you going to leave and close the house when he dies? Eve is not prepared for such a question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Why... No, I don't think so...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good. Chance smiles at Eve and there is a moment of silence before Eve steps back into her bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Good night, Chauncey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Eve. Eve closes the door. Wilson wheels Chance down the hallway toward the guest room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve comes out of the house, Jeffrey holds the door for her as she gets into "RAND l." Jeffrey gets in and the limo pulls away. Chance comes out of the front door, walking with a limp. His first view of the Rand grounds in the daylight, he is taken by the extent of the greenery. An attendant, LEWIS, hurries to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you want a car, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I would like a car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Lewis goes to his post, picks up a phone. As Chance looks at the surroundings, Allenby and Wilson, with Chance's wheelchair, come out of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, there you are. What are you doing on that leg?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's fine today, Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shame on you, Chauncey - you should let me be the judge of that. (motions to Wilson) Please, sit in the chair. Wilson pushes the wheelchair to Chance, he sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear, Chauncey, between you and Benjamin, I've got my hands full... (looks at calf) ... Say, that is coming along, the swelling has gone down considerably... (pokes a spot) ... Any pain here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Robert. But it's not bad. A limousine pulls up to the front of the mansion, waits for Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Benjamin has been hounding me to allow him to address the annual meeting of his Financial Institute today, but obviously, the strain would be impossible... How about here, Chauncey, any soreness?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hardly any, Robert. Lewis, the attendant, interrupts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your limousine, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Were you going somewhere?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Oh. (checks leg) ... My God, I only wish that Benjamin had your recuperative powers... Anyway, the President offered to sit in for Ben at the meeting, quite a nice gesture, I felt. He's due here soon, I believe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Robert. I know about the President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Oh? You've heard?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Ben called me. He wants me to meet the President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does, does he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ben told me to be in his room at ten o'clock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, that's terrific, Chauncey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do I know when it's ten o'clock? A long look from Allenby, then he looks at his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It's five of, you'd best get on in there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Robert. Wilson begins to push Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would like to walk today.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hell yes - walk. You're meeting the President, aren't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, really? Allenby, a bit puzzled, watches as Chance goes into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance limps aimlessly through a hallway. He stops, admires a large tapestry on the wall. A servant, SMYTHE, notices Chance appears confused, approaches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I help you, Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I would like to go to Rand Memorial Hospital.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. There is another long pause.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Did you wish to see someone, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I would like to see Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Rand, of course. Right this way, sir. Chance follows Smythe down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand is in an easy chair, dressed for his meeting with the President. The two nurses are working at the disinfecting table. Rand smiles as Chance is shown into the room by Smythe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, up and around this morning, are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ben. My leg is not very sore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, that's good news, my boy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking much better today, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hah! It's all make-up, Chauncey... I asked nurse Teresa to fix me up, I didn't want the President to think I was going to die during our talk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one likes a dying man, my boy - because few know what death is. All we know is the terror of it. But you're an exception, Chauncey - that's what I admire in you, your marvelous balance. You don't stagger back and forth between fear and hope - you're a truly peaceful man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Ben. (looks at Rand closely) ... The nurse did a very good job, Ben. The nurses turn, look at Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wilson is at the head of eight servants lined up on the front steps. Two black PLYMOUTH SEDANS pull up and park. EIGHT MEN in grey business suits get out. One of them, WOLTZ, goes directly to Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Wilson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Woltz, nice to see you again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. How have you been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, thank you. (hands Woltz paper) We have an additional guest with us today, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see... (turns to other men) Okay, let's go to work. The eight servants pair up with the eight men in suits and go into the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allenby gets off the elevator, stands and thinks for a moment, then heads off down the hallway in the direction of Chance's room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance watches television as Rand speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, when I was younger I had thoughts about public office... But I found, Chauncey - that I was able to contribute more as a private citizen... of course, my wealth provided me with considerable influence, but I've tried, believe me, not to misuse that power... It's extremely important, Chauncey, when one is in a position of eminence, that he does not allow himself to become blinded to the needs of the country... The temptations are strong, and I've been labeled a 'kingmaker' by many, but I have tried to stay open to voices of the people... I have tried to remain honest to myself...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Maybe one day you shall find yourself in a similar position, Chauncey... Maybe one day...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two black limousines followed by a station wagon with small holes in the side pull up in front of the mansion. As men from the first limousine and the station wagon jump out and take positions around the driveway, Lewis hurries to his post, picks up his phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AUBREY'S OFFICE - MORNING The nerve center of the Rand Enterprises since he has become ill. Four or five desks, all the latest electronic office equipment, three TV's with video taping facilities, countless telephones. MRS. AUBREY, Rand's senior secretary, is at her desk, answers her phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... Oh, very good, Lewis, thank you. Mrs. Aubrey hangs up, picks up another phone, pushes a button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand smiles at Chance as the phone rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's here. (into phone) Yes, Mrs. Aubrey? (listens) Fine. Show the President to the library, we'll be along in a few minutes. Rand hangs up the phone, turns to Chance with a twinkle in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's an old habit that goes along with power -- keep them waiting... Teresa brings Rand's wheelchair to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not now, Teresa. I'm seeing the President on my own two feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Mr. Rand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall we go, Chauncey?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ben. That's a good idea. Rand walks slowly, clings to the limping Chance tightly as they leave the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (puts an arm around Chance for support)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Secret Service Men are seen in the background as Rand stops outside Mrs. Aubrey's office, leans in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Aubrey, have you received the papers on the Caracas agreement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. They're ready for you to sign.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent. (turns to Chance) A good woman, Mrs. Aubrey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree, Ben. They shuffle off down the hallway. Chance smiles at the Secret Service men that they pass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woltz and Wilson wait by the library door. Woltz takes a small metal detector from his pocket as Rand and Chance approach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Woltz, how have you been?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just fine, thank you, sir. (turns to Chance) And you must be Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a formality, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you very much. Wilson knocks lightly, then opens the library door, Rand and Chance enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand and Chance come into the Library and the President goes to Rand with both hands outstretched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Mr. President, how good to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's so good to see you too, Ben, you look terrific!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not convinced of that, Mr. President, but your visit has raised my spirits...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I'm delighted to be here, my friend. I've missed you. (guides Rand to chair) Here, sit down, get off your feet. As Rand sinks into the chair, Chance approaches the President with both hands outstretched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Hello. Chance and the President exchange a two-handed handshake. Rand, still weak from standing, catches his breath and introduces Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. President, I'd like you to meet my dear friend, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, my pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look much taller on television, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Oh, really...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will find that my house guest does not bandy words, Mr. President. The President gives Chance a look, then laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, that's just fine with me - I'm a man that appreciates a frank discussion... Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Ben, did you happen to get a chance to... Chance perks up at the mention of his name, interrupts.
direction.name: direction
