direction.raw_text: Yes? There is a beat as the President looks at Chance quizzically, then he continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I just wondered if you had gone over my speech, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I did.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Overall - pretty good. But, Mr. President, I think it's very dangerous to resort to temporary measures at this stage of the game.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Ben... I...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I sympathize with your position, Mr. President, I know how difficult it is to be straightforward, the reaction to such a speech could be chaos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too big a risk, I can't take the chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes? Once again, the President gives Chance a puzzled look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perkins accompanies Secret Service Agent RIFF as he checks out the third floor. Riff knocks on each door, looks inside, then moves in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allenby is searching through Chancels clothes looking for some sort of identification. There is a knock at the door, Allenby pulls back from the closet as Riff opens the door, looks inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh... Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning. I'm Riff, Secret Service.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes. Of course. Perkins watches curiously as Riff passes the metal detector over Allenby's clothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President is worried about what Rand is telling him. He paces, smokes a cigarette. Chance smiles through it all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... There is no longer any margin for inflation, it has gone as far as it can, you've reached your limits on taxation, dependence on foreign energy has reached a crisis, and, from where I see it, Mr. President, the Free Enterprise System has reached the breaking point. We are on the brink of another crash from which recovery might not be possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's that serious, huh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid so. The President now looks nearly as bad as Rand. He sits, turns to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you agree with Ben, Mr. Gardiner? Are we finished? Or do you think we can stimulate growth through temporary incentives?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as the roots are not severed, all is well and all will be well in the garden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... In the garden?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is correct. In a garden, growth has its season. There is spring and summer, but there is also fall and winter. And then spring and summer again...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Spring and summer... (confused) Yes, I see... Fall and winter. (smiles at Chance) Yes, indeed... (a beat) Could you go through that one more time, please, Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think what my most insightful friend is saying, Mr. President, is that we welcome the inevitable seasons of nature, yet we are upset by the seasons of our economy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That is correct.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Well, Mr. Gardiner, I must admit, that is one of the most refreshing and optimistic statements I've heard in a very, very long time. The President puts out his cigarette, rises.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Many of us forget that nature and society are one! Yes, though we have tried to cut ourselves off from nature, we are still a part of it! Like nature, our economic system remains, in the long run, stable and rational. And that is why we must not fear to be at its mercy! (he smiles at Chance, who is absorbed in looking around the room at the books) ... I envy your good, solid sense, Mr. Gardiner - that is precisely what we lack on Capitol Hill. (glances at watch) I must be going. (holds out hand to Chance) Mr. Gardiner, this visit has been enlightening... Chance rises and shakes the President's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It has.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You will honor me and my family with a visit, won't you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wonderful, we'll all look forward to seeing you. (turns to Rand) Is Eve around? I'd like to say hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, she flew up to Boston for another charity event. She'll be sorry to have missed you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry, too. Well, Nancy wanted me to send along her best to the two of you - and, Ben, I want to thank you for your time and thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense, Mr. President - I thank you for coming to spend time with a dying man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, Ben, I won't have any of that. Why don't you listen to your good friend Chauncey this is a time to think of life! The President clasps Rand's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right, Mr. President I don't like feeling sorry for myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take care of yourself, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take care too, Bobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner... The President leaves the library and Chance sits back down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's a decent fellow, the President, isn't he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Ben - he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was quite impressed with your comments, Chauncey - he hears my sort of analysis from everyone, but yours, unfortunately - seldom if ever at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad he came, Ben. It was nice talking to the President.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (as he turns to go, a smile to Chance)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: An aide, KAUFMAN, waits by the front door of the Rand mansion. As the President comes out, he speaks quietly to Kaufman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaufman, I'm going to need information on Mr. Chauncey Gardiner's background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gardiner, yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And put it through on a Code Red - I want it as soon as possible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No problem, Chief. They head toward the waiting limousines.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand has an arm around Chance, hangs on for dear life as the two of them walk through the hall. Behind them, Wilson and Perkins push empty wheelchairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You know, Chauncey, there's something about you... You're direct, you grasp things quickly and you state them plainly. You don't play games with words to protect yourself. I feel I can speak to you frankly... You know what I was talking to you about last night?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, sure you do, the financial assistance program. I think you might be just the man to take charge of such an undertaking. I'd like you to meet with the members of the Board, we'll be able to discuss the matter at greater length at that time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And, please, Chauncey - don't rush your decision. I know you're not a man to act on the spur of the moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now, Chauncey, I'm afraid you must excuse me - I'm very tired all of a sudden. Wilson and Perkins leave the wheelchairs, assist Rand into his hospital room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry that you are so sick, Ben. The door closes, Chance limps off down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance, with a limp, walks down a pathway in the garden, admires the greenery. In the background, coming from the house, we see Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your leg must be getting better.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It's feeling much better now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. I'm glad to hear that. (they walk together) ... How did you like meeting the President?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. He's very nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, he is. I'm sorry I didn't get to see him. They walk along in silence for a moment. Chance sees a huge greenhouse not far from them, heads toward it. Eve turns to him, hesitates, then questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Chauncey... Last night you mentioned an old man, that died.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was he a relative? Or an intimate friend?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was a very wealthy man, he looked after me since I was young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I see... Your mentor, perhaps?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Mentor...? Eve takes his uncertainty as a reluctance to discuss the Old Man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me, Chauncey - I didn't mean to pry. You must have been very close to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I was. EVE I'm sorry... (getting more to the point) ... And what about Louise? YOU mentioned that she had gone, were you close to her also?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I liked Louise very much. She was his maid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, his maid!... Stupid me, I thought perhaps she was someone that you may have been romantically involved with.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no. She brought me my meals.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. Eve edges slightly closer to Chance. Chance edges slightly closer to the greenhouse, is fascinated by it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Our greenhouse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I like that very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, so do we. Chance peeks through one of the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand is in bed. Eve, Chance and Allenby are seated around him, the two nurses standing to one side. They all watch the President's address to the Financial Institute on TV. Chance inhales deeply, enjoys the oxygen in the room. Rand is looking weaker. Every so often, Allenby casts a concerned glance his way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And there are so many of you that have proclaimed that we are on the brink of the worst financial crisis in this nation's history. And there are so many of you demanding that we put into effect drastic measures to alter its course. Well, let me tell you, gentlemen, I have been conducting multiple-level consultations with members of the Cabinet, House and Senate. I have conducted meetings with prominent business leaders throughout the country. And this very morning I had an in-depth discussion with your founder and Chairman-Of-The-Board, Mr. Benjamin Turnbull Rand and his close friend and advisor Mr. Chauncey Gardiner... Rand perks up a bit at this mention. Allenby manages a smile, once again looks at Rand, checking his condition. Eve looks proudly at Chance, who continues to enjoy the oxygen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Well, gentlemen, I found this to be a most rewarding conference... To quote Mr. Gardiner, a most intuitive man, 'As long as the roots of industry remain firmly planted in the national soil, the economic prospects are undoubtedly sunny.' Rand starts coughing, breathing heavily. Allenby and the nurses rush to his bedside. Allenby shoots a quick look to Eve and Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse us, please. Eve and Chance leave the room as Allenby administers aid to Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gentlemen, let us not fear the inevitable chill and storms of autumn and winter, instead, let us anticipate the rapid growth of springtime, let us await the rewards of summer. As in a garden of the earth, let us learn to accept and appreciate the times when the trees are bare as well as the times when we pick the fruit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve and Chance sit in silence on the patio. Eve's eyes are swollen, red, she has been crying. She turns to Chance, reaches out, touches his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'm... (pause) ... I'm very grateful that you're here, Chauncey... (pause) ... With us ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So am I, Eve. Allenby comes out the door, his mood is serious, professional. Eve turns quickly, awaits his news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Eve - this has been an exhausting day for Ben...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... But he's...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's resting comfortably now. There's no cause for alarm, yet... Mrs. Aubrey comes out of the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, I have a telephone call for you. Sidney Courtney, the financial editor of the Washington Post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you care to take it, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Chance still does not move. Eve mistakes Chance's not moving for concern for herself. She puts a hand on his shoulder. EVE I'll be all right, Chauncey you go ahead with Mrs. Aubrey...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Eve. You'll be all right. Chance follows Mrs. Aubrey into the house. Eve watches him go, then turns to Allenby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... He's such a sensitive man, so considerate...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AUBREY'S OFFICE - DAY Mrs. Aubrey leads Chance to a phone at one of the desks. The three television sets are on, attract Chance's attention.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a Black man in his fifties, wears a rumpled wool jacket, smokes a pipe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mr. Gardiner. This is Sid Courtney, Washington Post.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AUBREY'S OFFICE / COURTNEY'S OFFICE CHANCE Hello, Sid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to disturb you, Mr. Gardiner, I know you must be very busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I'm not busy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then, I'll be brief. I covered the President's speech at the Financial Institute today, and since the Post would like to be as exact as possible, we would appreciate your comments on the meeting that took place between Mr. Rand, the President and yourself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President is a nice person. I enjoyed it very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good, sir. And so, it seems, did the President - but we would like to have some facts; such as, uh... What exactly is the relationship between yourself and that of the First American Financial Corporation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think you should ask Mr. Rand that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. But since he is ill I'm taking the liberty of asking you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, that is correct. I think you should ask Mr. Rand that. Courtney doesn't understand but continues his questioning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Then one more quick question, Mr. Gardiner; since we at the Post would like to, uh - update our profile on you - what exactly is your business?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have nothing more to say. Chance hangs up the phone, watches the TVs. Courtney listens to the dial tone, then puts the receiver down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Typical - no wonder he's so close to Rand...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (looking from one TV to the other)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Chance comes out of Mrs. Aubrey's office, notices the service elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm. Elevator. He gets in the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance looks at the row of buttons, presses one. He smiles as he feels the elevator move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of Mrs. Aubrey's secretaries, JENNIFER, waits with an arm load of paperwork for the elevator. The door opens, Chance smiles at her as he steps out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, hello, Mr. Gardiner - are you looking for someone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Jennifer gets in the elevator, the doors Close. Chance looks around the basement, puzzled. He had expected to be on the third floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . AUBREY'S OFFICE - DAY Mrs. Aubrey is at her desk, buzzing her inter-house phone. As Jennifer enters, Mrs. Aubrey hangs up in frustration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't find Mr. Gardiner anywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's in the basement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's he doing in the basement?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know, Mrs. Aubrey. Mrs. Aubrey grabs a notepad, leaves the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Aubrey comes out of the service elevator, hurries through the basement. She checks: The boiler room. The electrical room. The photographer's studio (Eve is sitting for a portrait) The gym (Allenby is working out)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance stands in the middle of the two-lane bowling alley, totally confused. Mrs. Aubrey enters, he smiles at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mr. Gardiner, I've been looking all over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening' just called.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I have seen that show on television.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course. They would like you to appear on the show tonight. The Vice President was scheduled, but he had to cancel, and they asked if you would be interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I would like to be on that show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. They felt that since you had such close ties with the President, you would be a splendid choice. (Chance nods, there is a pause) ... Can I help you? Are you looking for something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I like this attic very much. Mrs. Aubrey gives him a look, leaves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 1 passes through the clouds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President sits on a couch in one of the compartments on the jet. Before him, stand six of his STAFF, Kaufman included.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Gentlemen, I quoted this man on national television today he is obviously a financial sophisticate of some reknown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir - we are aware of all that, but still, we haven't been able to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's an advisor and close personal friend of Rand's! For Christ sakes, they have volumes of data on Benjamin!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Mr. President, we attempted to contact Mr. Rand, but he was too ill to...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not want Benjamin Rand disturbed! You have other ways of gathering information than to trouble a dying man. Use whatever agencies are necessary to put together a detailed history of Chauncey Gardiner, if you run into problems, alert Honeycutt. (he stands) I'll be in the office at seven in the morning and I would like to have it at that time. (he starts for door) I've got to take a leak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, Chief. As the President goes to the Men's Room, two of the aides reach for telephones.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance wears a velvet bathrobe, watches TV. Perkins lays out a suit, shirt, tie, etc. on the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I believe these garments will be quite appropriate, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. They are fine. There is a knock at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, sir. Perkins answers the door, it is Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, I just wanted to wish you well. I know you'll be smashing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And Benjamin sends along his best wishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is Ben feeling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's tired, Chauncey - but he's going to watch you tonight. We'll both be watching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good. I like to watch, too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you do - you and your television... (a pause) ... Good luck, Chauncey. Eve impulsively steps forward, kisses Chance on the cheek. Chance smiles at her, and Eve, slightly embarrassed, turns and leaves the room. Chance sits back down, watches TV as Perkins attends to his clothes with a whisk broom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Courtney heads a meeting of his four staffers. One man,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a research assistant, sits behind a stack of paperwork, has a downcast expression as he listens to Courtney.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Gardiner is laconic, matter-of fact. The scuttlebutt is that he's a strong candidate for one of the vacant seats on the board of First American. But before we can do any sort of a piece on the man, we're going to need facts on his background... (turns to Kinney) ... Kinney, what did you come up with?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Skip the levity, Kinney - what have you got?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I realize this sounds banal but there is no information of any sort on Gardiner. We have no material on him - zilch... The room is quiet except for the tapping of Courtney's pencil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The RAND 1 limousine parks in front of the station. As Jeffrey opens the door for Chance, MORTON HULL steps to the limo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, I'm Morton Hull, the producer of 'This Evening.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Morton. Hull takes Chance into the station.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constance, Rand's nurse, enters Chance's room, goes to the closet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance is intrigued by the surroundings as Hull guides him through the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Mr. Gardiner, the fact that you occupy such a position in the world of finance makes you ideally suited to provide our millions of viewers with an explanation of this nation's economic crisis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you realize, Mr. Gardiner, that more people will be watching you tonight than all those who have seen theater plays in the last forty years?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It's a very good show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you like it, Mr. Gardiner. Hull takes Chance into the MAKE-UP room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Constance is in the closet, searching through Chance's pockets, finding nothing. She takes out a small knife, cuts a label from one of the jackets. Quickly, she examines one of Chance's shoes, copies the name of the shoemaker in a notebook. Constance hurries to the dresser, continues her search.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the makeup man, comes through the corridor carrying a glass of water. He turns into the makeup room, goes to Chance who sits in front of the lights. Hull sits next to Chance, briefs him on the show. Chance has his eyes on a TV monitor, watches the guest preceding him on "This Evening."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you go, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. I'm very thirsty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir - it's hot under those lights. Colson applies finishing touches to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now, if the host wants to ask you a question, he'll raise his left forefinger to his left eyebrow. (Chance watches TV) Then you'll stop, and he'll say something, and then you'll answer. On the TV, WILLIAM DUPONT, the host, wraps up his talk with his guest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, Mr. Gardiner, you're all set. Hull leads Chance out of the makeup room. Colson closes the door, then carefully picks up Chance's water glass, wraps it in Kleenex, puts it in his overcoat pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: William Dupont introduces Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ladies and gentlemen, our very distinguished quest, Mr. Chauncey Gardiner! The BAND plays as Chance comes onto the stage. An audience of about three hundred applauds Chance as he appears. Two TV cameras move with him as he walks, with a smile and a limp, to center stage. Dupont shakes Chance's hand, Chance holds Dupont's hand with both of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, how very nice to have you with us this evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to thank you for filling in on such short notice for the Vice President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I always find it surprising, Mr. Gardiner, to find men like yourself, who are working so intimately with the President, yet manage to remain relatively unknown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That is surprising.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Well, your anonymity will be a thing of the past from now on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hope so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes... Of course, you know, Mr. Gardiner, that I always prefer an open and frank conversation with my guests, I hope you don't object to that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I don't object.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine, then let's get started. The current state of our country is of vital interest to us all, and I would like to know if you agree with the President's view of the economy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Which view? Applause and laughter from the audience. Dupont accustomed to parrying with his guests, asks again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, Mr. Gardiner, before his speech at the Financial Institute the President consulted with you and Benjamin Rand, did he not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I was there with Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know that, Mr. Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, let me rephrase the question; the President compared the economy of this country to a garden, and stated that after a period of decline a time of growth would naturally follow. Do you go along with this belief?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I know the garden very well. I have worked in it all my life. It is a good garden and a healthy one; its trees are healthy and so are its shrubs and flowers, as long as they are trimmed and watered in the right seasons. The garden needs a lot of care. I do agree with the President; everything in it will grow strong, and there is plenty of room in it for new trees and new flowers of all kinds. The audience applauds Chance's apparent metaphor. Dupont waits for it all to subside, then asks another question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand is in bed. Eve sits in a chair next to the bed, squeezes Rand's hand in excitement as they both watch Chance on television. Teresa, the nurse, watches in the background.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...Well, Mr. Gardiner, that was very well put indeed, and I feel it was a booster for all of us who do not like to wallow in complaints or take delight in gloomy predictions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President and First Lady are in bed together watching the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gloomy predictions? That insolent son of a bitch!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's make it clear, Mr. Gardiner, it's your view that the collapse of the Stock Market, the dramatic increase in unemployment, you feel that this is just another season, so to speak, in the garden? The First Lady cuddles close the President, ruffles his hair, tries to cheer him up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a garden, things grow - but first some things must wither; some trees lose their leaves before they grow new leaves...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small, dark room. A videotape machine is running. Also, a machine is turning that records the harmonics of Chance's voice. TWO CIA MEN run the equipment, watch as a needle charts Chance's voice onto paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Then they grow thicker and stronger and taller. Some trees die, but fresh saplings replace them. Gardens need a lot of care and a lot of love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin, the attorney that evicted Chance, comes out of the bathroom brushing his teeth. His wife, JOHANNA, is in bed absorbed in "This Evening." Franklin sits on the end of the bed, watches the show.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And if you give your garden a lot of love, and if you work very hard and have a lot of patience, in the proper season you will see it grow to be very beautiful... More applause from the TV. Franklin leans closer to the set.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's that gardener!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Chauncey Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No! He's a real gardener!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He does talk like one, but I think he's brilliant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I think your metaphors are quite interesting, Mr. Gardiner, but, haven't we seen seasons that have been devastating to certain countries?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President and First Lady continue to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Such as disasterous winters, prolonged droughts that have wiped out crops, hurricanes that have all but swept away island communities? Doesn't a country need to have someone in charge that can see it through such crises?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... That bastard... The First Lady moves closer to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The TV, its volume low, plays in the background as Constance, with a pair of tweezers, plucks a hair from Chance's pillow, puts it into a small vial.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't we need a leader capable of guiding us through the seasons? The bad as well as the good?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. We need a very good gardener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dupont continues his questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you feel that we have a 'Very good gardener' in office at this time, Mr. Gardiner? At the end of the question, Dupont glances over Chance's shoulder to look at the monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I understand. Chance turns to see what Dupont is looking at, sees the back of his own head on the TV screen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I realize that might be a difficult question for you, Mr. Gardiner - but there are a lot of us around the country that would like to hear your thoughts on the matter. Chance is still turned to the monitor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, yes. It is possible for one side of the garden to be flooded, and the other side to be dry...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allenby watches Chance on television. The camera that covered Dupont in close-up has now pulled back, includes Dupont and Chance, both looking into camera. Allenby is concerned, he is unsure of Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Some plants do well in the sun, and others grow better in the cool of the shade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A group of ELDERLY BLACK PEOPLE sit in the lobby, watch "This Evening" on an old black-and-white TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It is the gardener's responsibility to take water from the flooded area and run it to the area that is dry. It is the gardener's responsibility not to plant a sun-loving flower in the shade of a high wall... During the preceding speech, Louise, the maid from the Old Man's house, chatters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gobbledegook! All the time he talked gobbledegook! An' it's for sure a White man's world in America, hell, I raised that boy since he was the size of a pissant an' I'll say right now he never learned to read an' write - no sir! Had no brains at all, was stuffed with rice puddin' between the ears! Shortchanged by the Lord and dumb as a jackass an' look at him now! Yes, sir - all you gotta be is white in America an' you get whatever you want! Just listen to that boy - gobbledegook! There is a chorus of "Amens" as she finishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It is the responsibility of the gardener to adjust to the bad seasons as well as enjoy the good ones. If the gardener does his job, everything will be fine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Audience applause is heard over TV. Rand claps weakly along with the TV sound. Eve and Teresa also clap.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Splendid. Just splendid... Rand looks up as Constance comes into the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn, Constance, get in here! You shouldn't miss any of this! Constance hurries to Teresa's side. Rand turns to Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm becoming quite attached to Chauncey - quite attached... (Eve smiles) ... And so are you, aren't you, Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes, I am, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's good... That's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, Mr. Gardiner, from the sound of our audience, I'd say that your words are a most welcome respite from what we've been hearing from others...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dupont asks another question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry to say that our time is running short, but before we close, I'd like to ask one final question. What sort of gardener, sir, would you be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am a very serious gardener.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: More applause over the TV. The President pales.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jesus... He rolls over in bed. The First Lady reaches out, puts a comforting hand on his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Franklin holds a phone to his ear with one hand, shuts off the TV with the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, I'll see you in twenty minutes. Franklin hangs up the phone, scurries around getting dressed. His wife, Johanna, sits grimly in bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Business, bullshit! Going out in the middle of the night to meet that bitch in a bar...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sally Hayes is not a bitch - she's a damn fine attorney! I've got to talk to her about this Gardiner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, Johanna...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said good night! Franklin gives up, hurries from the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Colson, carefully carrying his overcoat, walks with Chance through the corridor. A delighted Hull walks behind them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Marvelous! Just marvelous, Mr. Gardiner! What spirit you have, what confidence! Exactly what this country needs! Chance smiles at well-wishers as they continue on through the corridor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The First Lady is snuggled up close to the President, caresses his body. After a moment, it becomes clear to her that he is not up to the occasion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Darling... What's wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I can't... I just can't right now... I'm sorry, dearest... I just can't... The First Lady looks at him for a beat, then turns, lies on her back and stares at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An 'in' meeting place for the upper-middle Washington, D.C. crowd. Thomas Franklin and Sally Hayes sit at a table, drinks in front of them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It didn't make any sense to me at all. I didn't know what the hell he was talking about...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wasn't making a speech to us, Tom - he was talking to the masses. He was very clever, keeping it at a third grade level - that's what they understand...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah? Well, I don't understand what was up his sleeve when he pulled that stunt with us? What was he doing? And why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who knows...? Maybe the government had something to do with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know, Sally - I really feel like I've been had, and you know what that means, don't you?... It means that any political future I had is right down the toilet! The CAMERA begins to slowly move away from the table, the sound of Franklin's voice continues.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Jesus, the thought of spending the rest of my life as an attorney, that is really a downer... And, Christ, Sally, I almost forgot Johanna is starting to think something's going on between... Franklin's voice fades into the background hubbub. The voice of Kinney, the research assistant from the Washington Post is heard as the camera settles on a table occupied by Sidney Courtney and his staff.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Sid, be reasonable - I've been everywhere, there's no place left to check!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure, try again - where? There's nothing, it's like he never existed!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sid, it's useless!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said - try again. Kinney stands, shoves his paperwork across the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Up yours, Sid. You try again, I quit! Kinney takes his drink with him as he leaves the lounge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The household staff is lined up on the front steps, applauding Chance as he steps from the limousine. Chance accepts the plaudit, though does not understand the reason. As he nears the steps, Perkins and Wilson step forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An outstanding speech, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I take your coat, Mr. Gardiner?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Thank you, Perkins. Perkins nods, takes Chance's overcoat, allows everyone to enter the house ahead of him. Alone on the steps, Perkins quickly searches through the pockets of the coat, finds nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand is in bed. Eve sits on the edge, looks warmly to Chance who stands nearby. Allenby prepares an injection for Rand, and occasionally glances curiously at Chance. Chance breathes deeply, enjoys the oxygen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You possess a great gift, Chauncey, of being natural. And that, my boy, is a rare talent, the true mark of a leader. You were strong and brave, yet did not moralize. I hope the entire country was watching you tonight, the entire country... Allenby crosses to Rand, needle in hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you, Benjamin, must be strong and brave for me. Turn over, please.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In a minute, Robert - in a minute... Chauncey, I would like to ask a favor of you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, Ben.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Senator Rowley's widow, Sophie, is hosting an evening reception tomorrow evening honoring Ambassador Skrapinov of the Soviet Union... I think it's rather obvious that Robert won't allow me to attend, so - would you go in my place, and escort Eve?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I would like to escort Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Together, the two of you should create quite a stir - I can already hear the gossip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Ben, really...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Thank you, Chauncey... Thank you very much. (takes back hand) ... All right, Robert, I'm all yours. Eve and Chance quietly leave the room. Allenby watches Chance go, then readies Rand for the injection.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reaches out a tired hand to Chance - Chance holds it)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The elevator door opens, Eve and Chance come into the hallway. Chance looks back at the elevator for a beat, then the two walk quietly down the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You don't happen to have a tuxedo in your suitcase, do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Well, we can fix up one of Ben's for you tomorrow night. Sophie insists an Black Tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I have very few friends, Chauncey... And Benjamin's friends are all quite a bit older... Eve gives Chance a long look, then kisses him on the lips. She steps back, smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Good night, Chauncey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, Eve. Eve goes into her bedroom, closes the door. Chance heads for his room as though nothing had happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kaufman and the five other Aides nervously await the President's arrival. The door opens, the President briskly enters the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, gentlemen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good morning, sir. The President leads the way into the Oval Office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the President goes to his desk, Kaufman hands him a folder. The President sits, reads it quickly, it is very brief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is not what I requested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This information goes back three days. I want the standard file, you know that.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right, Chief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So...? Where the hell is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We... uh, have been unable to come up with any information before the man appeared at Mr. Rand's home ... and, uh...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the hell are you talking about, Kaufman?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, we do have data from Honeycutt's sources, Chief - but it isn't pertinent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to hear that data, Kaufman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. Kaufman takes a clipboard from the man at his right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suits hand-made by a tailor in Chicago in 1918. The tailor went out of business in 1929, then took his own life. ... His shoes were hand-made in
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The cobbler has long since been dead. Underwear, all of the finest cloth, factory destroyed by fire in 1938. The man carries no identification; no wallet, no driver's license, no credit cards. ... He carries one item along with him, a fine Swiss pocket-watch crafted at the turn of the century; so far they have been unable to ascertain where or when purchase was made. ... He has never dyed his hair. ... Computers have analyzed Gardiner's vocal characteristics; it is impossible to determine his ethnic background, they feel his accent may be northeastern, but they will not commit to that. ... Fingerprint check proved negative, no identification possible. (a pause) ... That's it, Mr. President. The President stares at Kaufman for a beat, then speaks into his intercom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Davis - I'd like my eggs poached this morning, please. A quick "Yes sir" from Miss Davis over the intercom. The President leans back in his swivel chair, looks at Kaufman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... So what does all that add up to?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, sir - it occurred to us that he might be an agent of a foreign power. But, we ruled that out, as they invariably are provided with too much documentation, too much American identity... We, uh...don't quite know what to make of it yet, sir... But we'll keep on top of it, Mr. President - we'll come up with the answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would appreciate that. The Aides quickly leave the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chance is in bed, a bed tray on his lap, eating breakfast. A pile of the morning's newspapers lies at the foot of the bed, untouched. The TV is playing, Chance watches as he eats. There is a knock at the door. CHANCE (without turning from TV) Come in! Eve enters, wearing a robe over her nightgown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey! Have you seen the papers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Eve. I don't read the papers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, it seems you've been described as one of the architects of the President's speech. And your own comments from the 'This Evening' show are quoted side by side with the President's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like the President. He is a very nice man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... (a moment) ... So are you, Chauncey ... (another moment, Chance watches TV) ... Do you mind my being here, like this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Eve. I like you to be here. Eve smiles, moves a little closer to Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... You know, Chauncey... I want us to be... (with difficulty) I want us... You and I to become... close... I want us to become very close, you know...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Eve. I know that. Eve suddenly begins to cry, sobbing quietly at first, then losing control, the tears flowing freely. To comfort her, Chance puts his arm around her shoulder, nearly tipping his breakfast tray. Eve responds to his touch, draws closer, holds Chance tightly. Chance does his best to avoid spilling his breakfast, keep an eye on the TV, and to comfort Eve. She gives in to her desires, begins to caress Chance, running her hand over his body. She kisses him, his eyes, his neck, his lips, his ears. Chance does not return the lovemaking, and Eve eventually catches hold of herself, stops. She lies quietly beside Chance for a time, regains her demeanor, then speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I'm grateful to you, Chauncey... I would have opened to you with a touch, and you know that... (Chance,confused, turns to her) ... But you're so strong - I can trust myself with you. I'm glad, Chauncey - I'm glad that you showed so much restraint...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Eve. I'm very glad that you didn't open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you are, Chauncey... (a pause) ... You conquer a woman from within herself, you infuse in her the need and desire and the longing for your love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. That could be true.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I guess I may as well be honest about my feelings, Chauncey, as I know you are I am in love with you... I love you and I want you... And I know that you know it and I'm grateful that you've decided to wait until... Until... Eve cannot bring herself to finish the sentence. She rises, straightens her robe and moves toward the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... I do love you, Chauncey. A knock at the door startles Eve. She turns, opens it to
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the seam tress. Maggie carries one of Rand's tuxedos.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, come in, Maggie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, Maggie will alter Ben's tuxedo for you now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Eve leaves. Maggie stands by patiently as Chance eats his once-warm scrambled eggs and watches"Mr. Rogers Neighborhood" on TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Allenby is at his desk, searching through the Washington, D.C. telephone book. He finds a number, dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Thomas Franklin, please. (a wait) Is Thomas Franklin in? (a beat) Yes, this is Dr. Robert Allenby, would you please tell Mr. Franklin that I would like to talk to him? It concerns Chauncey Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teresa and Constance work in a corner of the room. Rand is in bed, very still, deep in thought.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The RAND 1 limousine pulls up to Sophie's house. Jeffrey opens the door for Eve and Chance. He wears Ben's tuxedo, Eve is in a formal gown. The press is waiting, a couple of reporters, 5 photographers and a mini-cam crew from local TV station gather around Eve and Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, what did you think of the Post's editorial on the President's speech?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't read it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But air - you must have at least glanced at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I did not glance at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, the New York Times spoke of your 'Peculiar brand of optimism,' what was your reaction to that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did not read that either.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, how do you feel about that phrase, 'Peculiar brand of optimism?'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not know what it means.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to persist, air, but it would be of great interest to me to know what newspapers you do read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do not read any newspapers. I watch TV. There is a moment of silence as the reporters digest this. The TV Reporter smiles, questions Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Do you mean, Mr. Gardiner, that you find television's coverage of the news superior to that of the newspapers?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like to watch TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mr. Gardiner, for what is probably the most honest admission to come from a public figure in years. Few men in public life have the courage not to read newspapers none have the guts to admit it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're welcome. Eve and Chance walk toward the front door, leaving the newsmen to talk among themselves. EVE I've never seen anyone handle the media as well as you, Chauncey. You're so cool and detached - almost as if you were born to it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Eve. The front door is opened for them by an attendant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Black Tie reception is in progress. The house is crowded, possibly a hundred guests, mostly foreign ambassadors and other such dignitaries. Eve and Chance enter, are greeted by
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a State Department official.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Rand, how good to see you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Watson.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you must be Mr. Gardiner, correct?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, this is Mr. Dennis Watson of the State Department.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Dennis.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pleasure to meet you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: an older woman bedecked with jewelry, approaches, embraces Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve, child! How nice of you to come.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Sophie. Sophie steps back, looks at Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And look who you brought with!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sophie, this is Chauncey Gardiner...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I've been just dying to meet you, Mr. Gardiner!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, this is Mrs. Sophia Rowley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Sophia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sophie, please - call me Sophie! Sophie pulls them both into the party, leaving Dennis looking after Chance as he walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You just have to let me introduce you to some of the exciting people here... Why, Pat Boone and his daughter may drop by later! They disappear into the crowd.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President is hunched over his desk, absorbed in constructing a model airplane, a World War II flying fortress bomber. The First Lady sits nearby, plays solitaire on a small table. The President glances to her, then back to his work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... How are the kids getting along?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh. Well, I just talked to Cindy this morning. She loves California, but to quote her, she says, 'The Secret Service is getting to be a drag.' I guess she wants her privacy...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Huh... I'm glad they're along with her, if you know what I mean... How about Jack?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, I think Jack needs some time alone with you, darling... He's getting to that age, you know... He really misses you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah... I'll have a talk with him as soon as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: at the door interrupts the President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Yes, come in! Kaufman enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to disturb you, chief but we have new developments.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh? What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have word that the Soviets have put out a top priority alert for information on Gardiner's background. So far, they haven't come up with a thing - what's more, as a result of their eagerness, one of their ablest agents blew his cover, we have him in custody at this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good. Anything else?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, chief - eight other foreign powers have put Gardiner under surveillance. We're around-the clock now, sir - I'll keep you posted. The President nods, Kaufman leaves. The President puts some more glue on the wing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sophie pulls Eve and Chance to AMBASSADOR SKRAPINOV and his
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Skrapinov smiles as he sees Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Rand. How delightful. Skrapinov kisses Eve's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems like ages, Mr. Ambassador. (a nod to his wife) Mrs. Skrapinov. Mrs. Skrapinov returns the nod as Sophie introduces Chance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, let me introduce you to our guest of honor, His Excellency Vladimar Skrapinov, Ambassador of the Soviet Union. Chance warmly shakes Skrapinov's hand with both of his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello... His... His...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ambassador Skrapinov, this is Mr. Chauncey Gardiner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Delighted. Delighted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And this is Mrs. Skrapinov. Chance smiles at Mrs. Skrapinov as The Ambassador puts an arm around him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must sit with us, my friend, we have much to discuss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I agree.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How is my dear friend Benjamin feeling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's doing as well as could be expected, Mr. Ambassador. He still speaks of the stimulating discussions he's had with you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, Yes. Please give him my regards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on, Eve. Let's let the men talk, there are so many people that have been asking about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you two excuse me for a moment?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Regretfully, Mrs. Rand - I shall yield the pleasure of your company to others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Eve. I shall yield too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be back soon... Eve and Sophie leave. Skrapinov leads his wife and Chance to their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry we haven't met sooner, Mr. Gardiner. I had the pleasure of seeing you on television last night and I listened with great interest to your down-to-earth philosophy. I'm not surprised that it was so quickly endorsed by the President. (quietly) ... Tell me, Mr. Gardiner, just how serious is Benjamin's illness? I did not want to upset Mrs. Rand by discussing it in detail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ben is very ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, so I've heard, a shame... As you know, we in the Soviet Union have the keenest interest in developments of the First American Financial Corporation... We are pleased to hear that you may fill Benjamin's place should he fail to recover. (arrive at table) Be seated, please, Mr. Gardiner. Chance sits between Skrapinov and Mrs. Skrapinov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Mr. Gardiner, I wish to be quite candid - considering the gravity of your economic situation, shouldn't we, the diplomats, and you, the businessman - get together more often?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I agree, I think so too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To exchange our thoughts - what does a Russian know about business? On the other hand, what does an American know about diplomacy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I have noticed in you a certain reticence regarding political issues - so why not a coming together? An interchange of opinion? We may find, my friend, that we are not so far from each other, not so far!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are not far... (motions at nearness of their chairs) ... our chairs almost touch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bravo! Bravo! Our chairs are indeed almost touching! And we want to remain seated on them, correct? We don't want them snatched from under us, am I right? Because if one goes, the other goes, and then - boom! Boom! And we are both down before our time, you see? And neither of us wants that, do you agree? CHANCE I certainly do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Tell me, Mr. Gardiner - do you by any chance enjoy Krylov's fables? I ask this because there is something... there is something Krylovian about you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think so? Do you think so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you know Krylov! Skrapinov pauses, then leans close to Chance, speaks softly in Russian. Chance, having never heard this language, raises his eyebrows and laughs. Mrs. Skrapinov remains impassive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you know your Krylov in Russian, do you? Mr. Gardiner, I must confess I had suspected as much all along - I know an educated man when I meet one!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it is very good!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it is. (beat) Would you tell me your name again, please?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ho! Ho! A dash of American humor! Vladimar Skrapinov!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I like that name very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And yours, sir - Chauncey Gardiner! (in Russian) How poetic! Chauncey, a name of uncertain meaning! And Gardiner, a bit of the French, a suggestion of a stroll through the flowers! A beautiful name, my friend! As he speaks in Russian, Eve comes to the table, taps Skrapinov on the shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs. Rand! You have returned to us!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only to steal Mr. Gardiner away, if I might. (to Chance) Everyone wants to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, Eve. That would be good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We must speak again, Mr. Gardiner, many times!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. As Eve and Chance leave, Skrapinov turns and nods to a MAN standing a short distance away. The man, KARPATOV, hurries to the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes? What have you found?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We have nothing on him, Ambassador Skrapinov.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Quietly, please. Mr. Gardiner, for one, understands our language.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry, Comrade Ambassador.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean there is nothing? That's impossible.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no information available on the man before he moved into Benjamin Rand's. It has proven to be such a difficult task that it has resulted in the loss of one of our agents to the United States Government. Mrs. Skrapinov strains to overhear the conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But... Where was this man Gardiner before last week?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Apparently the White House shares our curiosity - they have also launched an investigation, and, according to our sources, neither the F.B.I. nor the C.I.A. has met with success.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. Clearly, such interest on their part is of great political significance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Clearly, yes comrade.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm... Take this down. (Karpatov takes out notepad) I want this quote included in the Tass coverage; 'Chauncey Gardiner, in an intimate discussion with Ambassador Skrapinov, noted that "Unless the leaders of the opposing political systems move the chairs on which they sit closer to each other, all of their seats will be pulled from under them by rapid social and political changes."'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good, Your Excellency. Karpatov leaves the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: .C. COCKTAIL LOUNGE - NIGHT The same lounge as before. Sidney Courtney sits at the same table as earlier, only this time with the editor of the Washington Post, LYMAN STUART. Courtney puffs on his pipe as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It's strictly rumor at this stage, Lyman - just something in the wind... STUART Something rather big in the wind, I'd say. So whose files were destroyed? The CIA's or the FBI's?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. Like I said, it's just rumor so far, but we should start nosing around, see if we can talk to some people... The CAMERA begins to slowly MOVE AWAY from their table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... But why? The question is why? Why would they destroy Gardiner's files? What is it about his past they are trying to cover up? (his voice fades) ... A criminal record? A membership in a subversive organization? Homosexual, perhaps? The SOUND of Stuart's voice dissolves into Thomas Franklin's as the CAMERA SETTLES on Dr. Allenby and Franklin sitting at a table nearby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... And he told us that he had been living there since he was a child, working as a gardener. He showed us a room in the garage, where he said he stayed, and I... Well, I didn't really believe him, of course - but why the act?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no idea...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another thing that baffles me, Doctor - what was his connection with the deceased? Major financial dealings, obviously - but our firm has no record of any such transactions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hmmm. You say he showed you his garden?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, he said it was his, he walked us through it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see. (leans close to Franklin) Mr. Franklin, I must ask you and Miss Hayes to keep this incident with Mr. Gardiner to yourselves. There's no telling what he was involved in, and the matter may be extremely confidential. So please, not a word.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, Doctor, I understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine. Thank you, Mr. Franklin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Certainly, glad to be of help. Allenby rises, leaves the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eve and Sophie are talking to a small group. Chance moves away to get an hors d'oeuvre and is approached by RONALD STIEGLER, a publisher.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, I'm Ronald Stiegler, of Harvard Books.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello, Ronald.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Gardiner, my editors and I have been wondering if you'd consider writing a book for us? Something on your political philosophy. What do you say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't write.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course, who can nowadays? I have trouble writing a post card to my children! Look, we could give you a six figure advance, provide you with the very best ghostwriter, research assistants, proof readers...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't read.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of course not! No one has the time to read! One glances at things, watches television...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I like to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you do! No one reads!... Listen, book publishing isn't exactly a bed of roses these days...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What sort of bed is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rand is in bed. Sitting nearby are two attorneys, MONROE and
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Mrs. Aubrey stands to one side and Constance and Teresa prepare an IV for Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything. I said everything and that's exactly what I mean.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Mr. Rand, the holdings are so extensive, I would like to be more precise in...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What could be more precise than everything...? Allenby enters the room, stands by the door, unnoticed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything to Mrs. Rand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Right - everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You two don't have to lecture me on the complexities of the situation, no one knows that better than myself... But you must understand that I have an endless faith in Mrs. Rand's abilities - I know that she will select the right person for guidance when she has the need... She has shared my life, gentlemen, she has given me far more pleasure than any of my so called assets... Life has suddenly become very simple for me now - I may be older than my years, and you might think me to be somewhat feeble... But I am still in love, gentlemen, thank God for that... Allenby silently leaves the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dennis Watson, of the State Department, talks with Chance in a corner of the living room. Dennis whispers something into Chance's ear and Chance gives him an innocent smile. Dennis is encouraged by the smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We could do it now, we can go upstairs. (no reaction from Chance) ... Please, it's time for us. Come upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I like to watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Watch? You mean just watch me? Doing it alone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. I like to watch very much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, if that's what you want, then I want it too. (takes Chance's arm) We can go this way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want to tell Eve.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell Eve? You mean Mrs. Rand?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, you can tell her later. She'll never miss you in this crowd. Dennis leads Chance out of the crowded room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A light from the adjoining bathroom filters into the darkened bedroom. The President and the First Lady are in bed. They each lie on their backs, a distance apart and are silent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Maybe you should talk to somebody, darling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, that won't do any good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Is it me? Is there something I've done?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no, sweetheart - it's not you...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your damn job. It never happened when you were a senator...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not that, I just... The inter-White House phone rings, the President reaches for it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, Kaufman - what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chief, we have a break in the case. Our man at the Washington Post says they are working on a story that either the CIA or the FBI destroyed Gardiner's files before anyone could get to them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What? Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't say at this time - neither agency will admit to a thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Okay, get both Directors over here, I'll be right down. The President hangs up the phone as the First Lady stares at the ceiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A small room exquisitely decorated in pale lilac tapestry. The lights are very dim, and Dennis, who we cannot see, is lying on the floor. Dennis' clothes are draped over a chair. Chance sees a very small pocket television on a desk. He turns the TV on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can you see well?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, very well, thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you like it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. It's very tiny, but it's good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Are you sure you like it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I do, it's very good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Really? Really!!! Chance reacts to the change in tone of Dennis' voice, turns to look at him on the floor. Hearing the groans and heavy breathing, Chance thinks Dennis is ill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you need a doctor? I could call Robert...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want Robert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your foot! Give me your foot!! Dennis reaches out with his free hand, grabs Chance's foot, pulls it to himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. But my leg is still a little sore. Chance watches as Dennis goes through some spasms, then his body relaxes. Chance is concerned for Dennis' health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you sure you're not ill? We hear a contented sigh from the man on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A long, black limousine with a Red Star on the door pulls away from Sophie's house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: a high-ranking KGB officer, and two of his underlings are in the limousine, along with Skrapinov, his wife and Karpatov. Novogrod and his men wear heavy clothing, fresh from Moscow. They all drink vodka. (Dialogue in Russian, English subtitles)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The rank-and-file in the FBI feel he is FBI, but others feel he is a
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: man who knows how to destroy
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: files.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That could be possible...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But we are quite certain, comrade, that this man Gardiner is a leading member of an American elitist faction planning a coup d'etat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A coup d'etat! Of course, that was foreseen by Lenin himself!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is correct, Comrade Skrapinov. We have ascertained that Gardiner heads a big-business power group that will soon be taking over the American government.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Big business. I could work with that faction quite nicely, Colonel Novogrod.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have proven that already, Comrade Skrapinov, you are to be congratulated for recognizing the importance of this man and establishing an early friendship.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Colonel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us toast to the success of the coup. They all raise their glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Na zdorov'e! The men and Mrs. Skrapinov drink their vodkas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The reception is breaking up. Eve, wearing her coat, searches for Chance in the crowd. She sees him, taps him on the shoulder from behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Chauncey, where have you been? I was afraid you got bored and left, or that you were with some mysterious woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. I was with a man. We went upstairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Upstairs? Chauncey, you're always involved in some sort of discussion...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was very ill, I stayed with him for a while.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It must be the punch, and it is stuffy in here -- I feel it a little myself. You're an angel, my dear - thank God there are still men like you around to give aid and comfort. Eve and Chance leave the reception.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The President sits behind his desk in a bathrobe, his hair mussed. Standing before him are GROVER HONEYCUTT, the Director of the F.B.I., and CLIFFORD BALDWIN, C.I.A. Chief. Kaufman stands to one side. All are red-eyed, tired, and frustrated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I never gave such a directive, Mr. President.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nor I, sir - it would be out of the question.
direction.name: direction
